RT @yhn Watch: @SenTuberville delivers maiden floor speech   #alpolitics
By @sean_yhn https://yellowhammernews.com/watch-u-s-senator-tommy-tuberville-delivers-maiden-floor-speech/
When we empower our young people with a quality education, we give them the gift of an opportunity -- the greatest gift our country can give our citizens.

One thing I’ve learned, is that education is the key to freedom. Freedom to live the life you want. I’ve seen firsthand how education can give you a leg up and a way out. It’s a way to achieve the American Dream. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1366519956687495169/img/PWBszR1YEVZ6SgsP.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1366519956687495169/vid/480x270/KuQcf-EHyiI5y3Qp.mp4?tag=13
I coached young people from all backgrounds – rich, poor, and everybody in between. I mentored young people of all races, religions, and economic backgrounds.

I’ve been an educator, a coach, and a mentor to young people for 40 years. I recruited 18- and 19-year-olds from all over the country and all walks of life. I saw how they lived. I was a father-figure to hundreds of young men who had one or no parents. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1366519846419185665/img/ZDdiE6OomUPTORLU.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1366519846419185665/vid/480x270/40LNbUOhn6xOgzBC.mp4?tag=13
It’s humbling. It’s an opportunity to serve my country that I respect, cherish, and will always honor.

I delivered my first floor speech as a United States Senator for the great state of Alabama today. With over 513,000 American and 186,000 Mexican lives lost to COVID-19, both countries must work together to fight this deadly virus and protect the lives, livelihoods, and economies of our border communities  – from California to Texas. 

Let’s take on this challenge, @POTUS! 💪🏽

Last Congress, I introduced the Binational Health Strategies Act.

This legislation would protect border communities and create a binational strategy with identical policies and resources to confront COVID-19 and future public health threats. I’ll re-introduce it this week.

The U.S.-Mexico relationship is a critical one. We share a nearly 2,000-mile border and our economies and societies are inextricably intertwined – especially in border communities. 
Cross-border collaboration and urgent action are needed to tackle this health and economic crisis.

🧵As @POTUS and Mexican President @lopezobrador_ hold their first bilateral meeting today, it is imperative to keep in mind that this deadly global pandemic won’t be defeated anywhere until it is defeated everywhere.

We’ve got a calculator for that: https://elizabethwarren.com/calculator/ultra-millionaire-tax?ms=soc-WB-team-tw-wealth-tax-rollout-03-01-21

In 2019, I said that if Mitch McConnell used the filibuster to hold a Democratic Senate majority hostage—and block us from getting things done for the American people—we would need to get rid of the filibuster.

It’s time. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvaduCLXIAYhY5u.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1366452573008453642/vid/320x320/l7nqj7C79-q5yc8B.mp4?tag=13

A #WealthTax is critical for raising revenue, and that revenue is critical for raising opportunity. We build a future for all of our kids by investing in opportunity. This is one way we can make this government work for everyone—not just the rich and powerful.

This would generate at least $3 trillion for President Biden’s big agenda to #BuildBackBetter: expanding the caregiving economy from child care to nursing homes, rebuilding infrastructure, high quality k-12 education, and tuition-free public college and technical schools.

Since the pandemic crisis started, billionaire wealth has shot up 40%, while millions remain unemployed and families struggle to keep a roof over their heads and food on the table. It’s time for a #WealthTax to make ultra-millionaires and billionaires pay their fair share.

Right now, we live in an America tilted toward the ultra-rich and the powerful. The tax system is so full of loopholes and special breaks that families in the top 0.1% pay about 3.2% of their wealth in taxes while the bottom 99% pay about 7.2% in taxes.

Today, with @PramilaJayapal & @RepBrendanBoyle, I’m introducing a bill for a two-cent #WealthTax on net worths above $50 million—a few cents more for billionaires. This will raise at least $3 trillion to #BuildBackBetter and increase opportunity for all.

@J_I_Fisher Yeah, but I was making a different point.  The coops I've known expensed the maintenance much earlier since the economic model doesn't differentially reward capitalization.  So they have less worry on the back end since less undepreciated capex.

@beezy_melt ...having multiple vaccines that have gone from bench scale to arms this quickly, now running 2.5M doses/day and rising is still pretty amazing.  Managing the logistics is hard.  But the PH officials I speak with are good people, doing a heck of a job with too few resources.

@beezy_melt It's far from perfect.  We would have been vastly better off if the prior administration had nationalized vaccine roll out instead of leaving it to individual states to solve all these issues.  No one is arguing to the contrary.  BUT...

@beezy_melt e.g., the best locations to get people in county X vaccinated aren't necessarily the locations in their county, even though that individual then shows up as a % vax'd in their community. PH officials managing statewide roll out have to factor those issues in.

@beezy_melt To point (b) vaccines are being sent to county PH departments but people who reside in a given county may be getting vaccinated in the county they work, or the county where their doctors office is, etc.

@beezy_melt Reaching those people takes time and if you prioritize reaching them you are necessarily going to slow the rate of increase in % vaccinated.  But if your only metric is peak % vax, the political incentive is to get the easiest-to-reach people vaccinated first.  No perfect answers

@beezy_melt To point (a), some of the people with greatest propensity to spread COVID are also hardest to reach.  Bus drivers working 2 shifts/day. Homeless.  Multi-generational families living in one home w/ mixed immigration status.  etc.

@beezy_melt And while I can't explain all the discrepancies (there are a lot of data gaps), keep two things in mind:  (a) % vaccinated is an imperfect analogue for rate of slowing COVID spread and (b) % vaccinated by region isn't equivalent to % vaccinated in a region

@beezy_melt To be clear, no one is asking for fewer vaccines right now, and I didn't raise the point to be pollyanna-ish.  It was just to make sure people understand that a two-dose vaccine + a process that ties patients to both doses creates inventory management challenges for PH officials

This Committee understands that long-term investments in child care and paid family leave will reduce child poverty and improve gender and race equity. We fought to support working families in the #AmericanRescuePlan and will continue to advocate for equity in the 117th Congress.
Without affordable and accessible child care and paid family leave options, many women will be unable to return to the workforce, turning the clock back on decades of progress.

This issue is intersectional. In Black families—which are more likely to have all available parents working—working parents earn 40 percent less than white working parents, and therefore have a higher proportionate demand for, and more trouble affording, child care.

According to a USA Today analysis, the number of women with child care-related absences in any month more than doubled from 2019 to 2020. Women accounted for 84 percent of all workers who missed work in the average month last year due to child care issues.

The Ways and Means Committee is no stranger to the disproportionate impact of #COVID19 on working women, nearly 3 million of whom have been forced to leave their jobs, many to care for children who can't go to school or daycare. https://www.thelily.com/20000-day-cares-may-have-closed-in-the-pandemic-what-happens-when-parents-go-back-to-work/?tid=more_from_lily

Obviously, as soon as we can, we must end the filibuster that currently exists in the U.S. Senate. Given the enormous crises facing working families today, we cannot allow a minority of the Senate to obstruct what the vast majority of the American people want and need.

My own personal view is that the Senate should ignore the parliamentarian’s advice, which is wrong in a number of respects. I am not sure, however, that my view at this point is the majority view in the Democratic Caucus.
But even more importantly, I regard it as absurd that the parliamentarian, a Senate staffer elected by no one, can prevent a wage increase for 32 million workers.
Needless to say, I was extremely disappointed by the decision of the parliamentarian who ruled that the minimum wage provision was inconsistent with the Byrd Rule and the reconciliation process.

At a time when millions of workers are earning starvation wages, when the minimum wage has not been raised by Congress since 2007 and stands at a pathetic $7.25 an hour, it is time to raise the minimum wage to a living wage.
This week, as part of the reconciliation bill, I will be offering an amendment to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.
